courseTitle: Chemistry of Life: Bonding and Properties of Water

pageData.text: To understand how cells and organisms are assembled, we must first understand the fundamentals of atomic structure. We must understand how atoms are linked together, what type of chemical bonds are used, and how these bonds, as well as other chemical interactions, can form larger molecules. These chemical interactions are responsible for the unique properties or characteristics of certain molecules.

In this investigation, three types of chemical bonds will be investigated: ionic, covalent, and hydrogen. In a series of activities, some of the properties of water will be tested and the molecular interactions at play will be examined. In the first activity, the <button class='glossary-text'>solubility</button> of covalent and ionic substances in <button class='glossary-text'>polar</button> <button class='glossary-text'>solvents</button> is investigated. The physical properties of <button class='glossary-text'>adhesion</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>cohesion</button> of water due to <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bonding</button> is examined in the second activity. In the third activity, we investigate density and miscibility, and in the final activity, we observe the high heat capacity of water.

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Chemistry of Life: Bonding and Properties of Water

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Perform basic experiments to investigate the properties of chemical bonds.

Demonstrate and explain the physical aspects of water, such as <button class='glossary-text'>surface tension</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>adhesion</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>cohesion</button>, polarity, density, and heat capacity.
Discuss the intermolecular forces between <button class='glossary-text'>polar</button> substances and <button class='glossary-text'>nonpolar</button> substances.
Explain <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bond</button> formation and relate how hydrogen bonds are involved in the structure of water.

pageData.text: Human Blood freezes at around 31 degrees Fahrenheit. Water in the Arctic is consistently about 28 degrees Fahrenheit, and the freezing point of fish blood is about 30 degrees Fahrenheit. Although it seems like fish would freeze in the Arctic's coldwater temperatures, they do not. Like other animals that live in extremely cold environments, they have adapted to freezing temperatures. Anti-freeze proteins in fish prevent water molecules from being able to form ice crystals.

Anti-freeze proteins in cold-adapted animals are much better than man-made ones. Researchers are hopeful that by studying fish and other animals that live in the Arctic, they will be able to engineer a better anti-freeze for human use. Some of the possible applications of these include better anti-freezing agents for cars, low-calorie ice cream, and for human use during deep space travel.

pageData.desc: A fish laying on the ice.
pageData.altText: A fish laying on the ice.

pageData.text: Ionic Bonding are typically formed when a metal atom loses one or more electrons to become a positively charged , and when a nonmetal atom gains one or more electrons to become a negatively charged . These opposite charges cause the cation and anion to be attracted to each other, forming an ionic bond. Because ionic bonds form crystalline structures, ionic compounds are often very hard. Table salt (sodium chloride) is a good example of an ionic compound that exists in crystalline form. Ionic bonds are broken when ionic substances are dissolved. For example, when table salt is dissolved in water its crystalline form is broken down. Ions in are important for conducting the electrical charges that play a critical role in proton pumps, heart rhythms, and nerve impulses in the body.

Covalent Bonding are typically formed when two nonmetal atoms share one or more pairs of electrons. They can be classified as or . A nonpolar covalent bond forms when two atoms share electrons equally. A polar covalent bond forms when two atoms share electrons unequally. Unequal sharing is a direct consequence of which is the relative ability of an atom to attract electrons. If one atom is slightly more electronegative than the other in a covalent bond, the shared electrons will be pulled slightly closer to that atom, giving it a partial charge. The existence of partial charges on each of the atoms results in polarity of the molecule.

In covalent molecules, the atoms are held together by strong covalent bonds. When covalent bonds are broken, stored chemical energy is released. For instance, the covalent bonds of glucose, a simple sugar, can be broken to provide the energy used to generate adenosine triphosphate (ATP).

SolubilityLiquid mixtures of substances can be categorized into three main groups: , , and . Suspensions are heterogeneous mixtures that spontaneously separate into their individual components. A common example is a suspension of fine clay particles, which will eventually settle to the bottom if the mixture is left standing. Colloids are stable heterogeneous mixtures in which the particles do not separate into their individual component molecules (as in a suspension) but also will not spontaneously separate into layers. Some common examples of colloids include smoke and gelatin. Solutions are homogeneous mixtures in which the separates into individual molecules or ions that are evenly distributed throughout the .

<button class='glossary-text'>Solubility</button> is the ability of a substance to dissolve. More precisely, solubility is the maximum amount of solute that can be dissolved in a given amount of solvent at a specific temperature and pressure. If a substance dissolves in a solvent, it is <button class='glossary-text'>soluble</button>. If it does not dissolve, it is <button class='glossary-text'>insoluble</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Miscible</button> substances are liquids that are completely soluble with each other, whereas <button class='glossary-text'>immiscible</button> substances are insoluble with each other.

The substance that is able to dissolve other substances is the solvent, and the substance that is dissolved is the solute. When water is used as a solvent, the resulting solution is said to be <button class='glossary-text'>aqueous</button>. For example, if you stir a spoonful of sodium chloride into a glass of water, sodium chloride is considered the solute and water is the solvent. The mixture is an aqueous sodium chloride solution.

In a <button class='glossary-text'>saturated</button> <button class='glossary-text'>solution</button>, the amount of <button class='glossary-text'>solute</button> dissolved cannot be increased for that volume of <button class='glossary-text'>solvent</button> under those conditions. You can keep adding more and more sodium chloride to a glass of water until eventually the solution becomes saturated, and any more added sodium chloride will settle to the bottom of the glass regardless of how much you stir.

The solubility of one substance with another is often challenging to predict. Despite the numerous exceptions that exist, there are general rules that can be applied. <button class='glossary-text'>Polar</button> substances are more <button class='glossary-text'>soluble</button> in polar solvents, whereas <button class='glossary-text'>nonpolar</button> substances are more soluble in nonpolar solvents. This is known as the “like dissolves like” rule.

Water is often called the “universal solvent” because, as a highly polar substance, it is able to dissolve many solutes, especially ionic compounds and polar molecules. Substances that are easily dissolved in water are often described as <button class='glossary-text'>hydrophilic</button> (“water-loving”). It is important to remember that not all substances can be dissolved in water. Think of a salad dressing containing water, vinegar (acetic acid), and vegetable oil. You need to shake this kind of dressing before pouring it onto your salad because the water and vinegar solution will not dissolve the nonpolar vegetable oil. In fact, the water and vinegar solution forms one layer and the vegetable oil separates into another. Therefore, the vegetable oil would be described as <button class='glossary-text'>hydrophobic</button> (“water-fearing”).

Another commonly used solvent is isopropanol (rubbing alcohol), which is a polar molecule that exhibits less polarity than water. Isopropanol can dissolve some nonpolar substances, but it can also mix with water and other polar solvents. This allows for the creation of solutions that might otherwise be <button class='glossary-text'>immiscible</button>.

pageData.question: Which of the following molecules is LEAST likely to dissolve in water?

options.text: All molecules are equally soluble in water.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Non-polar molecules do not dissolve in water and are considered hydrophobic.

pageData.question: Which of the following substances can be described as hydrophobic?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Vegetable oil, such as that found in salad dressing, does not dissolve in water and is therefore hydrophobic.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Covalent bonds are typically formed when two nonmetal atoms share one or more pairs of electrons. There are two different types of covalent bonds: nonpolar and polar. A nonpolar covalent bond forms when two atoms share electrons equally. A polar covalent bond forms when two atoms share electrons unequally. Unequal sharing is a direct consequence of electronegativity. If one atom is slightly more electronegative than the other in a covalent bond, the shared electrons will be pulled slightly closer to that atom, giving it a partial charge. The existence of partial charges on each of the atoms results in polarity of the molecule.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak> The solubility of one substance with another is often challenging to predict. Despite the numerous exceptions that exist, there are general rules that can be applied. Polar substances are more soluble in polar solvents, whereas nonpolar substances are more soluble in nonpolar solvents. This is known as the “like dissolves like” rule. Water is often called the “universal solvent” because, as a highly polar substance, it can dissolve many solutes, especially ionic compounds and polar molecules. Substances that are easily dissolved in water are often described as hydrophilic (“water-loving”). Substances that do not dissolve in water are described as hydrophobic (“water-fearing”).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Covalent bonds are typically formed when two nonmetal atoms share one or more pairs of electrons. There are two different types of covalent bonds: nonpolar and polar. A nonpolar covalent bond forms when two atoms share electrons equally. A polar covalent bond forms when two atoms share electrons unequally. Unequal sharing is a direct consequence of electronegativity. If one atom is slightly more electronegative than the other in a covalent bond, the shared electrons will be pulled slightly closer to that atom, giving it a partial charge. The existence of partial charges on each of the atoms results in polarity of the molecule.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak> The solubility of one substance with another is often challenging to predict. Despite the numerous exceptions that exist, there are general rules that can be applied. Polar substances are more soluble in polar solvents, whereas nonpolar substances are more soluble in nonpolar solvents. This is known as the “like dissolves like” rule. Water is often called the “universal solvent” because, as a highly polar substance, it can dissolve many solutes, especially ionic compounds and polar molecules. Substances that are easily dissolved in water are often described as hydrophilic (“water-loving”). Substances that do not dissolve in water are described as hydrophobic (“water-fearing”).

pageData.text: Adhesion and Cohesion of WaterThe water molecule has a simple structure: one oxygen atom is covalently bonded to two hydrogen atoms. In addition to the two pairs of electrons it shares with the hydrogen atoms, the highly electronegative oxygen atom has a pair of unshared electrons. Due to this uneven sharing of electrons, a water molecule has a partial negative charge (δ–) near the oxygen atom and partial positive charges (δ+) near the hydrogen atoms (Figure 1). between adjacent water molecules result from an electrostatic attraction between the partial negative charge of the oxygen atom and the partial positive charge of the hydrogen atom. Hydrogen bonds are relatively weak; thus, they are constantly breaking and reforming as water molecules move around one another.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A space filling diagram of a water molecule. The molecule has a partial negative charge near the larger oxygen atom. The partial negative charge is denoted by the symbol delta minus. The molecule has partial positive charges near the smaller hydrogen atoms. Each partial positive charge is denoted by a delta plus symbol.

pageData.text: The attraction between water molecules due to hydrogen bonding is known as <button class='glossary-text'>cohesion</button> (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>). Water forms droplets due to cohesion. For the same reason, water is resistant to objects passing through its surface, and thus is said to have a high <button class='glossary-text'>surface tension</button>. Some organisms, like the water strider (a type of insect, Figure 2) and the common basilisk (a type of lizard), exploit this property when walking or running across the surface of water.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A water strider insect walking on the surface of water.

pageData.text: The attraction of water molecules with other different molecules is termed <button class='glossary-text'>adhesion</button>. Water clinging to a dog’s fur is an example of adhesion. Think of how hard a dog has to shake in order to dry its fur. This illustrates the power of adhesion.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Four water molecules attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds. Each hydrogen bond forms between a partially positive hydrogen atom and a partially negative oxygen atom from a different water molecule.

pageData.text: Heat Capacity denotes the amount of energy required to raise the temperature of 1 g of a substance 1°C. Water’s specific heat capacity is high, so it requires a relatively large amount of energy to change the temperature of water. A substance with a low specific heat capacity requires much less energy to change its temperature. This property of water is extremely important for life on Earth.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A lake surrounded by trees.

pageData.text: A body of water, such as a lake, maintains a relatively constant temperature throughout a 24-hour period even though the ambient temperature may rise and fall drastically between day and night. This helps maintain a constant environment for organisms that live in the water.

pageData.question: Water takes a long time to heat up and a long time to cool down because of which of the following?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water’s specific heat capacity is high, so it requires a relatively large amount of energy to change the temperature of water.

pageData.question: Which property of water helps maintain a constant environment for organisms that live in the water?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The high specific heat capacity of water means bodies of water take a long time to change temperature, which makes a stable habitat for aquatic organisms.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Water is extremely important for life on Earth. A body of water, such as a lake, maintains a relatively constant temperature throughout a 24-hour period even though the ambient temperature may rise and fall drastically between day and night. This is because water’s specific heat capacity is high, so it requires a relatively large amount of energy to change the temperature of water. A substance with a low specific heat capacity requires much less energy to change its temperature.

pageData.desc: A map of the first half of the investigation. Before starting any activities, collect some tap water and label the pipets. In Activity 1, you will add solvents and solutes to their designated wells. Then, you will observe the solubility of the solutes in each well. In Activity 2, you will add solvents and pepper to their designated wells. Then, you will dip a splint and a soapy splint into designated wells. Finally, you will observe adhesion and cohesion phenomena before continuing to Activity 3.
pageData.altText: A map of the first half of the investigation. Before starting any activities, collect some tap water and label the pipets. In Activity 1, you will add solvents and solutes to their designated wells. Then, you will observe the solubility of the solutes in each well. In Activity 2, you will add solvents and pepper to their designated wells. Then, you will dip a splint and a soapy splint into designated wells. Finally, you will observe adhesion and cohesion phenomena before continuing to Activity 3.

pageData.desc:
A map of the second half of the investigation. In Activity 3, you will add water to a well, then layer isopropanol on top of the water. Next, add pepper to each well and stir the mixture. Finally, observe the density and miscibility of the liquids. 
In Activity 4, you will add water to a paper cup. Next, ignite a split and hold it to the bottom of the cup. Then, hold the splint to the top of the cup and observe the paper ignition at each site.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

pageData.altText: flammable symbol
pageData.text: Use isopropanol (rubbing alcohol) with caution. Avoid contact with skin and eyes, and use in a ventilated room. Keep isopropanol away from heat, sparks, and flames.

pageData.altText: warning symbol
pageData.text: Keep combustible materials, including hair and clothing, away from flames. Do not leave open flames unattended. Know the location of your nearest accessible fire extinguisher and how to use it.

pageData.altText: corrosion symbol
pageData.text: Benzoic acid is harmful when swallowed, and can cause serious eye damage. It may cause respiratory irritation, drowsiness, or dizziness. Benzoic acid is toxic to aquatic life.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of these bonds is formed due to the opposite charges of cations and anions being attracted to each other?
Which of these refers to the relative ability of an atom to attract electrons?
Which type of bond will form when two nonmetal atoms share one pair of electrons?
Which of these is the part of a solution that dissolves in the solvent?
Vegetable oil in salad dressing requires you to shake the dressing to mix up the oil, water, and vinegar before pouring it onto a salad. Which of the following best describes vegetable oil?
Which of the following properties of water prevents large bodies of water from experiencing drastic temperature changes between day and night?
When fine clay is mixed in water and left to stand, the clay will settle to the bottom of the container.  Which term best describes this mixture?
Which of the following safety hazards is associated with isopropanol (rubbing alcohol), which will be used during this investigation?

options.text: It will stain skin or clothing.
It is extremely harmful to aquatic life.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety hazards is NOT associated with the benzoic acid provided for this investigation?

options.text: It will stain skin or clothing.
It is toxic to aquatic life.
It can cause serious eye damage.

assestmentData.question: Which of these properties of water explains why a dog must shake so hard to dry its fur?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Clean work area.
Collect about 100 mL of tap water in the 250-beaker.
Use a permanent marker to label one dropper pipet as “water” and the other as “isopropanol.” These pipets should be used only with their designated liquids.

In Activity 1, you will observe the <button class='glossary-text'>solubility</button> of different <button class='glossary-text'>solutes</button> in isopropanol versus water by observing whether, and how quickly, each solute dissolves in each <button class='glossary-text'>solvent</button>.
Orient the well plate such that A1 is in the top left corner. This table summarizes the contents of each well as described in steps 2-12 below.
Use the “isopropanol” pipet to transfer 2 mL of isopropanol into wells A1, A2, and A3.
Use the “water” pipet to transfer 2 mL of water into wells B1, B2, and B3.
Add one leveled scoop of table sugar (sucrose) to wells A1 and B1.
Be sure to use a clean scoop for each chemical.
Use clean wooden splints to stir each well for 30 seconds as you attempt to dissolve the solute.
Record your observations about the of table sugar (sucrose) in each in Data Table 1.
With a clean scoop, add one leveled scoop of table salt (sodium chloride) to wells A2 and B2.
Use clean wooden splints to stir each well for 30 seconds as you attempt dissolve the solute.
Record your observations about the solubility of table salt (sodium chloride) in each solvent in Data Table 1.
With a clean scoop, add one leveled scoop of benzoic acid to wells A3 and B3.
Use clean wooden splints to stir each well for 30 seconds as you attempt dissolve the solute.
Record your observations about the solubility of benzoic acid in each solvent in Data Table 1.

In Activity 2, you will compare isopropanol and water in terms of <button class='glossary-text'>adhesion</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>cohesion</button> by observing what happens when pepper is added to each <button class='glossary-text'>solvent</button>. You will then determine whether these properties can be disrupted by the presence of wooden splints dipped into each substance.
Orient the well plate such that A1 is in the top left corner. This table summarizes the contents of each well as described in steps 2-10 below.
Use the pipet labeled “isopropanol” to transfer 1 mL of isopropanol into wells C1, C2, and C3.
Use the pipet labeled “water” to transfer 1 mL of water into wells D1, D2, and D3.
Add a pinch of pepper to each well, allowing it to float or sink as it may.
Record your observations in Data Table 2.
Dip a wooden splint very slowly into well C2 so that it does not disturb the pepper layer, and then lift it back up out of the well. Record your observations.
Dip a wooden splint very slowly into well C2 again until it touches the bottom of the well, and then slowly lift it back out. Record your observations.
Coat the end (about 1 cm) of a clean wooden splint with a thin layer of soap and dip it into well C3.
Record your observations in Data Table 2.
Repeat steps 7-9 with the water in wells D2 and D3.
In Activity 3, you will observe the density and miscibility of water and isopropanol by adding the two substances together.
Use the pipet labeled “water” to transfer 1 mL of water into well D6.
Gently pipet an additional 1 mL of isopropanol on top of the water.
Dispense the isopropanol so that it runs down the side of the well to meet the water.
Record your observations in the Lab Notebook.
Add a pinch of pepper to each well, allowing it to float or sink as it may.
Record your observations in the Lab Notebook.
Use a wooden splint to stir the water and isopropanol, and record your observations in the Lab Notebook.
In Activity 4, you will observe the heat capacity of water by igniting a water-filled cup below and above the water line and comparing the results.

typeBefore.text: Caution: Before starting Activity 4, make sure all flammables, including the isopropanol used in Activities 1-3, are put away. Monitor all burning items closely and continuously during this activity.

pageData.text: Add about 50 mL of water to a paper cup and place it in an empty sink.
Use a match or lighter to ignite a clean wooden splint. If you are using a match to light the splint, douse the match with water once splint is lit.
While holding the water-filled cup, touch the flame to the bottom of the cup. Note that the cup does not burn.
Set the cup down in the sink and light the rim of the cup above the water line.
Allow the cup to burn just until the flames die down.
When burning is complete, douse the entire cup and splint with water.
Record your observations in the Lab Notebook. If you want to conduct a second trial, use the second cup.

text: Dispose of the paper cup and wooden splints in the trash.
Dispose of the <button class='glossary-text'>solutions</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>suspensions</button> down the drain. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse the lab equipment and return materials to the equipment kit.
Clean your work space.

data.title: Adhesion
data.content: the attraction of one type of molecule to other types of molecules

data.title: Anion
data.content: an ion with a net negative charge

data.title: Aqueous
data.content: a solution in which the solvent is water

data.title: Cation
data.content: an ion with net positive charge

data.title: Cohesion
data.content: the attraction between like molecules due to hydrogen bonding

data.title: Colloid
data.content: a stable heterogeneous mixture that will not separate into its individual component molecules (as in a suspension) nor spontaneously separate into layers

data.title: Covalent bond
data.content: a chemical bond in which there is a sharing of an electron pair between two atoms, giving both atoms a filled outer shell

data.title: Electronegativity
data.content: the relative ability of an atom to attract electrons

data.title: Hydrogen bond
data.content: a bond formed between an electropositive atom, usually hydrogen, and a strongly electronegative atom, such as oxygen or nitrogen

data.title: Hydrophilic
data.content: describes a substance that is attracted to water, "water-loving"

data.title: Hydrophobic
data.content: describes a substance repelled by water, "water-fearing"

data.title: Immiscible
data.content: describes liquid substances that are insoluble with each other

data.title: Insoluble
data.content: describes a substance that does not dissolves in a solvent

data.title: Ionic bond
data.content: a chemical bond formed when one atom, typically a non-metal atom, gives up one or more electrons to another atom, typically a metal atom, resulting in ions with filled outer shells for both the metal and non-metal atoms

data.title: Miscible
data.content: describes liquid substances that are completely soluble with each other

data.title: Nonpolar
data.content: describes a covalent bond in which two atoms share electrons equally; also describes a molecule with no net charge

data.title: Polar
data.content: describes a covalent bond in which the distribution of electrons is uneven (one end is positive and the other end is negative); also describes a molecule with partial charges that are not cancelled out

data.title: Saturated
data.content: describes a solution in which the amount of solute dissolved cannot be increased for that volume of solvent under those conditions

data.title: Solubility
data.content: the ability of a substance to dissolve

data.title: Soluble
data.content: describes a substance that dissolves in a solvent

data.title: Solute
data.content: the substance that dissolves into another substance (the solvent)

data.title: Solution
data.content: a homogeneous mixtures in which the solute separates into individual molecules or ions that are evenly distributed throughout the solvent

data.title: Solvent
data.content: the substance into which another substance (the solute) dissolves

data.title: Specific heat capacity
data.content: the amount of energy required to raise the temperature of 1 gram of a substance 1°C

data.title: Surface tension
data.content: the tendency of a liquid, due to the cohesive nature of its molecules, to behave like an elastic sheet

data.title: Suspension
data.content: a heterogeneous mixture that spontaneously separates into its individual components
